newsitem.title: USA: Niagara Mohawk hydro licenses extended.
newsitem.headline: Niagara Mohawk hydro licenses extended.

text.p: Niagara Mohawk Power Corp said Tuesday the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission has issued to the utility a new license to continue operating eight vintage hydroelectric power plants on the Beaver River in Lewis and Herkimer counties, New York.

The 30 year license, issued under the Federal Power Act, covers the Moshier Hydroelectric Station in the Town of Webb; the Soft Maple, Effley, Elmer, Taylorville, Belfort and High Falls plants, all in the town of Croghan, and the Eagle hydro project in the town of Watson.
Their combined total generating capacity will be maintained by Niagara Mohawk at 44,800 kilowatts, it said.
The new license came after more than a decade of environmental reviews and as many years of detailed regulatory proceedings, the company noted.
A key feature of the FERC license calls for establishment of a Beaver River Fund financed through yearly contributions by Niagara Mohawk over the license duration.

The Beaver River hydro sites date back to the turn of the century and are among 30 Niagara Mohawk hydroelectric stations, most of them on northern New York waterways, due for FERC relicensing in the 1990s.
